John Cocke

Biography

John Cocke was born in Charlotte, North Carolina (US), on the 30th May 1925. He passed in Valhalla, New York, on the 16th July 2002. In 1946 he graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Engineering in Mechanical Engineering from the Duke University and in 1956 he obtained his PhD in mathematics. Cocke spent his entire career working at IBMâ€™s T.J Watson Research Center from 1959 to 1992. Simultaneously, he worked as visiting Professor at MIT and Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences of New York University.

Research

John Cocke made ground braking contributions to the structure of high performance computers and to the blue print of optimizing compilers. His researches and findings are still used to a certain degree in modern Computer Architecture. One of his biggest achievements was the creation of the RISC (Reduce Instruction Set Computer). He also made great contributions to design and theory of the compiler, which is an accurate code translator of programming languages.

Awards and Honors

Year Award
1972 IBM Fellow
1979 Member, National Academy of Engineering
1985 Eckert-Mauchly Award (shared by the ACM and the IEEE Computer Society)
1986 Fellow, American Academy of Arts and Sciences
1987 ACM Turing Award
1988 Honorary Doctor of Science, Duke University
1989 IEEE Computer Society Pioneer Award
1990 IBM John E. Bertram Award for Sustained Excellence
1991 National Medal of Technology
1993 Member, National Academy of Sciences
1994 NEC Foundation Computers & Communications Prize
1994 National Medal of Science
1996 The Franklin Institute's Certificate of Merit
1999 Seymour Cray Computer Science and Engineering Award
2000 the Benjamin Franklin Medal
2002 Fellow of the Computer History Museum
Turing Award of 1987

In memory of A.M. Turing
